sense.name: cease operating
sense.commentary: Includes: CLOSE OFF Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] CLOSE (NP2[patient]) (NP2[patient]) CLOSE (NP1[agent]) Note: 'close off the compressor' implies the activity the compressor is engaged in, e.g., filling tanks with compressed air Note: usually implies a habitual activity or operation that is ceases.
sense.examples: The car repair shop closes at noon on Saturdays. Our favorite bakery was closed due to a fire. The old bookstore finally closed its doors last summer. Highway 9 has been closed for two days because of mud slides. Close all running applications before starting this process on your PC. That restaurant was closed down by the Board of Health. Close off the compressor because there are engine fumes in the vicinity. They had to close up shop because of lack of funds.

sense.name: shut or become in a shut state
sense.commentary: Includes: CLOSE UP, CLOSE OFF, CLOSE IN Syntax Is: (NP1)[agent] CLOSE NP2[concrete] (NP1)[agent CLOSE_IN NP2[concrete] (PP{P NP[instrumental}) (NP1)[agent] CLOSE_OFF NP2[concrete] NP1[agent] CLOSE_UP NP2[patient] NP1[agent] CLOSE_UP
sense.examples: I can't close my car window. She is always closing doors behind her. The lid closed on the piano bench with a heavy thud. I'd better close my mouth before I say something I'll regret. The horses were closed in by a high wooden fence. They had to close off the main gas line that connects to the houses on our street. Mary was closed off from her friends and life by a long bout with depression. The mummy was closed up in the tomb by slaves. She closes up whenever John enters the conversation.

sense.name: terminate or conclude an activity
sense.commentary: Includes: CLOSE OUT Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] CLOSE PP NP1[agent] CLOSE NP2[patient] NP1[agent] CLOSE OUT NP2[patient] Note: usually implies specific events or activities, rather than habitual general ones.
sense.examples: The meeting was closed without deciding on who would be club president. He likes to close dinner speeches with a good joke. She closed her recital with a beautiful folksong. I hope stocks will close higher at day's end. That relief pitcher has closed six games this season, winning all of them. That fashion house has closed out its line of evening wear. John will be closing out his account at his old bank.

sense.name: draw near to, approach
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[topic] CLOSE PP{P NP[goal]}
sense.examples: A meteorite appears to be closing with our spacecraft! The southern cavalry closed with Union forces on the battlefield. Close on your opponent's left and catch him off guard. The police were closing in on the suspect.

sense.name: bring parts together, join
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] CLOSE NP2[goal] PP NP1[agent] CLOSE NP2[goal] ADVP
sense.examples: The pincers of the big crab closed on John's hand. She closed a blanket around the shivering child. He closed the wound with a series of small stitches. This umbrella won't close properly. The party has closed ranks during this political scandal. You need to close up a few loose ends in the logic of your story's plot.

sense.name: bring about, accomplish
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] CLOSE PP NP1[agent] CLOSE NP[goal]
sense.examples: We are closing on the house tomorrow. Don't go into sales if you can't close deals.

sense.name: fill in, repair
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] CLOSE[transitive] NP2[patient] Note: implies that NP2 has two end points, between which something is filled.
sense.examples: Try closing those cracks in the ceiling with this new compound. They are trying to close the income gap between the urban poor and the middle class.

sense.name: preclude or rule out
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] CLOSE OUT NP2[patient]
sense.examples: They were closed out of society based only on the color of their skin. Don't close out this opportunity before you've had a chance to learn more about it.
